poem:
Title: Fire and Consequence

In the confluence of a terrible dawn,
His body became a tongue of protest.
The Pentagon, grim witness—silent.
An airman, but a man first,
Streaming not life, but a fiery dissent.
The unmoving fortress watched,
Aligned with the indifferent sun.
In flames, he found an end,
Voiced not in shouts, but in sparks.
Echoed is his cry: "No longer complicit".
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. An active-duty member of the US air force, Bushnell livestreamed his death, from the moment he said he would “no longer be complicit in genocide” to the moment he poured fluid over himself and burst into". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
